The temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are believed to be the Houses of the Lord. In them, ordinances of exaltation are performed for worthy members. These included baptism for the dead, being endowed with the priesthood of God, and eternal sealings to spouses and children.

There are currently 300 temples around the world that are operating, under construction, under renovation, or in the planning stages. When a temple is completed, the doors are opened for a short time to allow anyone who wishes to see the inside. Once the temple is dedicated as the House of the Lord, however, the doors are closed except to those worthy and active church members who have been recommended to enter by their local leaders.

If someone leaves the Church, they become one of the general public and are not allowed to enter the temple. They are, of course, welcome to attend any worship service in a local meetinghouse of the Church, as are all visitors.

Original question: What is the deal with Mormons and temples? Can they enter their own temple once they leave Mormonism? If so, why and how does that work exactly?

We aren’t called “Mormons” anymore, but rather Latter-day Saints. The temple is the House of the Lord. He is the one who determines its entry requirements. Those requirements include being a faithful member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

If you leave the Church, that’s fine. You can build or buy your own temple and decide who gets to come into it.

What documents should I get after closing a home loan in India?

The documents you should get after closing your home loan are:

1. Original Documents: You must get all the original documents you submitted to the lender at the time of availing the loan. Ensure that the documents are in good condition, with all the pages intact. The documents may include:

a. Sale Deed

b. Title Deed

c. Loan Agreement

d. Power of Attorney

The documents you should get after closing your home loan are:

1. Original Documents: You must get all the original documents you submitted to the lender at the time of availing the loan. Ensure that the documents are in good condition, with all the pages intact. The documents may include:

a. Sale Deed

b. Title Deed

c. Loan Agreement

d. Power of Attorney

2. No Dues Certificate: A No Dues Certificate (NDC) or No Objection Certificate (NOC) states that all dues have been settled and that the lender does not have any rights or claim on the property. Your NDC should mention critical details related to the housing loan (property address), customer name(s), the loan account number and amount, and the dates of starting and closing of the loan. It is advised that you make copies of the NOC so any future deals related to the property go smoothly.

3. Updated Non-Encumbrance Certificate: A Non-Encumbrance Certificate is a legal document containing detailed records of all financial transactions related to the property. Once you have settled your housing loan, the repayment should be reflected in the Non Encumbrance Certificate.

4. Post-dated Cheques: Your lender may have required you to submit post-dated cheques in the event of any missed EMI. If you have always been on time with your payments, make sure you retrieve all the submitted post-dated cheques.

In addition to these documents, there are two tasks that you need to complete:

1. Removal of Lien on the Property: At times, lenders may put a lien on the property. This effectively prevents the customer(s) from selling the property. In such cases, the lien must be removed after the repayment of the loan. To remove the lien, visit the Registrar’s Office along with an official from the lender’s side.

2. Make Sure Your Credit Records are Updated: Check if your credit records are updated after you repay your home loan. Usually, it takes around 20-30 days for the repayment to be reflected in your credit history. Subsequently, request a credit report and verify the updated record.

Can Mormons enter a temple (with a recommendation) just for the sake of going in, or can you only enter the temple when there for a ceremony?

I respect the various opinions expressed in the answers to this question, and this is one great thing about being a Latter-day Saint; there’s no indoctrination, and everyone is welcome to interpret the doctrine according to the inspiration of the Holy Spirit.

My mother often goes to the temple with my father (i.e. every other time), who is a temple worker, but as she is legally blind, she cannot read the cards, and so prefers to remain where she does not need to serve.

The Montreal Quebec temple does not have a Chapel, but only a waiting room with a tiny dining room; my mother can often be found there, and she entertains those who arrive and wait for a session to start.

No one at the temple will ask what you are doing there, unless it is either for small talk, or because they need you somewhere. There is no sign up, or any time limit in being there. Of course, the best place to be waiting is in the Celestial room, but you must have served somewhere in order to enter. That’s the only restriction I know.

One evening, the temple had just opened and everyone but me (about 6 people) were in the opening session. (This is the time when only temple workers can enter past the front desk.) There came one member who was visiting from Columbia, and he was with a non-member friend. As he was early, and seeing nobody around, he asked if I could allow him to tour the temple for his friend. I apologized, and invited him to the lounge. He stayed there for about 15 minutes, then left. He did ask, however, to take a picture in front of the temple, and I gladly helped them with that.

Temples are really a piece of heaven on earth, where everything is done orderly, and without any stress. Just being there is comparable of being alone in the woods… where there is only nature and peace. The difference with that, though, is that there is a sense of purpose in the temple that does not really exist in the wilderness.

To me anyway.

What do Mormons believe happens inside their temples?

Original question: What do Mormons believe happens inside their temples?

I believe it because I see it. We perform sacred rituals we call ordinances. Then we go back and repeat them in behalf of our deceased ancestors who never had the chance to do it themselves.

We spiritually bind ourselves to Jesus Christ. We make these same blessings available to others.

One thing we don’t do is call ourselves “Mormons.” We are Latter-day Saints.

What's a good investment for 2023?

Around the world, we’re hearing news of economic downturns and inflation. Start the new year on the right note by making intelligent investment decisions in 2023. Ideally, you should find an investment that does not rely wholly on the market. Here are some ways you can invest in the new year:

Fixed Deposits (FDs)

One of the most traditional ways to invest and keep money safe, FDs provide steady returns on your principal. FDs come with long lock-in periods and low to medium returns, making them reliable but not always adequate to help you meet your financial goals. This is one of the best investm

Around the world, we’re hearing news of economic downturns and inflation. Start the new year on the right note by making intelligent investment decisions in 2023. Ideally, you should find an investment that does not rely wholly on the market. Here are some ways you can invest in the new year:

Fixed Deposits (FDs)

One of the most traditional ways to invest and keep money safe, FDs provide steady returns on your principal. FDs come with long lock-in periods and low to medium returns, making them reliable but not always adequate to help you meet your financial goals. This is one of the best investment option for individuals with a low risk appetite.

Unit-Linked Insurance Plans (ULIPs)

ULIPs provide investment opportunities with the added financial protection of life insurance. A chunk of your ULIP premium gets invested in debt and equity funds of your choice. They provide returns as per market conditions. The rest of the premium goes towards providing life coverage. These plans are ideal for individuals looking to grow a corpus for a specific goal. They have a lock-in period of five years but work best when they remain active for up to ten years. ULIPs allow fund switches, so you can move your money from one type of fund to another to maximise your returns based on market conditions.

Gold ETF

Gold ETFs function like mutual funds and get traded online. Through a gold ETF, individuals can purchase gold electronically. Generally, gold gets viewed as a safe investment since the price of gold often does not depend on the market. Very often, gold prices rise when the market dips. Gold ETFs allow investors to quickly and efficiently purchase and sell gold electronically.

National Pension Scheme

The National Pension Scheme (NPS) helps individuals save and invest for the golden years. You can consider the scheme when saving for retirement. It matures whenever you reach 60 and comes with minimal risks. You can expect returns of around 10-11%.

Public Provident Fund (PPF)

The PPF allows investors to enjoy low risks with guaranteed returns of around 7-8%. The PPF is an ideal investment for those who want to fulfil long-term financial goals and supplement their retirement fund.

You can make prudent choices by understanding the investment options available to you. Choosing options like ULIPs allow you to benefit from investment opportunities, life coverage and tax benefits.

Can non-Mormons enter Mormon temples? Why do Mormons spend time in temples?

Whenever a new temple is built or an older one is renovated, there is a period of time when the Church puts on an open house. During that time the general public is given guided tours of the temple. After the temple is dedicated, it is then closed to the public and only members with temple recommends can enter. More information here:

https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/temples/open-houses?lang=eng

I was hoping to go to the Temple, tomorrow night, but I just pulled out my Temple Recommend and saw it has expired.

I converted to the LDS, after being a Roman Catholic for over four decades, in 2014. I stepped out of line and was "benched" (placed on probation over pre-marital sex), for six months. Upon restoration of my callings and discussions with my Bishop, I was sent to Temple prep classes and sought my Recommend.

Today is the two year anniversary of my first entry into the Temple, here in Denver. I will not speak of what takes place in there, but I will describe my feelings.

I was a cop in Los Angeles for over 30 years. Whenever I entered a rich person's home I felt out of place, creeped out, undeserving. Temples are beautifully decorated and the furnishings are luxurious (you can usually Google images of various Temples, taken prior to dedication). Entering the Temple, it felt like I BELONGED there. Do all Mormons have to go to the temple?

Original question: Do all Mormons have to go to the temple?

We are not called “Mormons” anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

Nobody forces us to go to the temple. We go there to worship God in the way he has appointed, to seek the blessings that come from making covenants with Him there, and to extend those blessings to our ancestors who never had the opportunity in their lifetimes.

Does technology help or hinder society’s well-being?

TL;DR:
Just as with everything else, there are two ways to look at this and two outcomes of the question. Although the reality is subjective and this cannot be answered with a yes or no, because both are equally good answers with relevant valid-real-life examples to either side.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Lets start analyzing this with Quora itself and then move on to other examples of technology.

Case 1: Quora (and of course other similar websites and forums for free information including edulix, wikipedia, XDA, reddit [bite me], twitter and other social networks too)
Good: There is high quality content on Quora, provided by users like Balaji Viswanathan (பாலாஜி விஸ்வநாதன்), Leonard Kim, Bhuvi Jain, User-12616619705513344996, Judith Meyer, Ken Nakagama, Claire J. Vannette, Ian Morgan, Dan Bradbury, Eivind and more (many I am unaware of and some who I don't follow yet). Contributing answers for topics and fields from economics, politics, religion, technology, start ups and entrepreneurship, relationship advices, food and cuisines, languages and culture and what not. For each question, in most cases, the top 20 answers will cover almost everything there is to know about it-- high quality. On edulix aspiring students can get free profile evaluations for the probability of their candidacy at their dream institutions of advanced studies.

Bad:- Sadly some people who just want to get popular/upvotes/I-dont-know-what answer to a question which already has good answers without contributing to the knowledge pool or adding any quality to it.

A truck load lot of questions on relationships and dating problems (mostly coming from Indian demographic) are getting repeatedly asked; new questions even if the same has been asked in just another set of words.
Not completely bad in itself but people need to be a tad more patient and diligent in looking for answers- chances are someone else has been where you are and someone else has treaded that area successfully. Look for it.

Don't multi-post if you're not adding quality to the content and only quantity.

A lot of questions and answers which are biased, especially if related to religion and politics; similar to how most of the journos and media personnel who prefer to provide *spiced* and *sensational* news reports, rather than facts, which ends up reducing the quality.

Case 2:- Smartphones (or cellphones in general)
These are definitely good, when you use it for communication and learning from it. good

bad:- if you are glued to your phone 24*7 playing games and texting friends, trying to hook up with online dating while there are people (some family, your colleagues and friends) right in front of you. You may be an introvert and prefer to be in isolation (in your own world and alone) which is okay.

Case 3: Laptop-Tablets-Computers. Even Television
very similar to smartphones, you could actually just combine the two as one case. Use them to read, study, watch encyclopedias, articles and shoes of National Geographic, Discovery etc and its good. Watch only movies and play games, you're wasting your time.

Case 4: Automobiles
Good: helps you move around with your family in comfort and travel on your own time. When you carpool. Useful (especially in Europe where trains are generally the expensive transportation method) to travel longer distances from one city to another, because it ends up being cheaper for you. Newer technology brings better fuel efficiency, more reliability etc.

bad: if you end up driving to the drug store-medicine shop-chemist which is 5 minutes of walk from your house. When you don't carpool. When you over-speed, drink and drive, participate in illegal street racing (go become an F1- Nascar driver if you like to race and win), especially for pedestrians

Case 5: Robots and Machinery.
Good: Reduces human errors and fatality in hospitals, factories with dangerous work environments because they are robust and most reliable, have less fatigue compared to human counter parts.

Bad: Because it puts people out of jobs. Can be misused for thefts.

Case 6: Use of Technology in (bio)chemicals.
Good: Develops vaccines, medicines to tackle epidemics, malaria, common cold, HIV, Cancer and everything else. Bring artificial rain. Protecting crop harvest from pets and insects by developing pesticides. Higher durability varnish and paints, teflon, other hygroscopic materials and other things which will have extensive applications in future for many purposes currently unfathomable. and more.

Bad: Using technology to create bio-weapons, weapons of mass destruction (yes you can thank me President Obama) and more.


Each good and bad is dependent on how you think what is good and bad for you.

There is no single answer, neither a pure and emphatic YES nor a jubilant NO.

Thanks for putting this question in my A2A list quora. But I am sure a similar question has been asked before.

Rodney, it surprises me that you’re asking this question. The question should be revised to ask, “What is a Latter-day Saint Temple?” The RLDS/CoC use their temples for completly different purposes (conferences and other meetings) and I’m not sure what Fundamentalist Mormon groups use theirs for other than eternal marriages and sealings.

Latter-day Saints believe the temple is a house of God–a place to worship and participate in sacred ordinances and to make special covenants with God. One of those ordinances is temple marriages and sealings to form eternal families. We also do vicarious baptisms and confirmations for our ancestors and others. Our temples are not normal meeting houses. In fact, all temples are closed on Sundays when members typically go to church in most parts of the world.

Tours are conducted through temples prior to their dedication for those who are not members of the Church and just want to see the inside. With 10 to 20 new temples being dedicated each year throughout the world, it’s fairly easy to find one being shown in an openhouse. There are also many pictures online showing the inside of our temples.

Do Mormons have to pay to get a temple recommend?

No.

Full stop.

Feel free to set a recommend interview with your local Bishop. He will ask the following questions, free of charge, and sign the paper, free of charge:

  1. Do you have faith in and a testimony of God, the Eternal Father; His Son, Jesus Christ; and the Holy Ghost?
  2. Do you have a testimony of the Atonement of Jesus Christ and of His role as your Savior and Redeemer?
  3. Do you have a testimony of the Restoration of the gospel of Jesus Christ?
  4. Do you sustain the President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints as the prophet, seer, and revelator and as the only person on the earth authorized to exercise all priesthood keys?

    Do you sustain the members of the First Presidency and the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles as prophets, seers, and revelators?

    Do you sustain the other General Authorities and local leaders of the Church?
  5. The Lord has said that all things are to be “done in cleanliness” before Him (Doctrine and Covenants 42:41).

    Do you strive for moral cleanliness in your thoughts and behavior?

    Do you obey the law of chastity?
  6. Do you follow the teachings of the Church of Jesus Christ in your private and public behavior with members of your family and others?
  7. Do you support or promote any teachings, practices, or doctrine contrary to those of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
  8. Do you strive to keep the Sabbath day holy, both at home and at church; attend your meetings; prepare for and worthily partake of the sacrament; and live your life in harmony with the laws and commandments of the gospel?
  9. Do you strive to be honest in all that you do?
  10. Are you a full-tithe payer?

    For new members seeking a limited-use recommend: Are you willing to obey the commandment to pay tithing?
  11. Do you understand and obey the Word of Wisdom?
  12. Do you have any financial or other obligations to a former spouse or to children?

    If yes, are you current in meeting those obligations?
  13. Do you keep the covenants that you made in the temple, including wearing the temple garment as instructed in the endowment?
  14. Are there serious sins in your life that need to be resolved with priesthood authorities as part of your repentance?
  15. Do you consider yourself worthy to enter the Lord’s house and participate in temple ordinances?

Yes, the scriptural admonition that we be willing to sacrifice everything to the Lord includes sacrificing your resources when he asks you to. That may be harder for some than others, depending on your idolatry of choice.

What do Mormons do in temples?

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. In my experience (I’ve seen many, many “debunking mormonism” type stuff) content not released directly by the church is almost always incorrect. Sadly, most of the time it is seemingly done intentionally. Lucky for us, the church has released many resources to tell people what the temple is and what’s done there.

I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothi

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. In my experience (I’ve seen many, many “debunking mormonism” type stuff) content not released directly by the church is almost always incorrect. Sadly, most of the time it is seemingly done intentionally. Lucky for us, the church has released many resources to tell people what the temple is and what’s done there.

I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothing I say speaks for the church in any official or unofficial way.

So what do we do in temples?

Well, we worship. We participate in ordinances for ourselves and for others. We reflect and meditate. We pray. We try to get close to God.

In the temple, we have a handful of ordinances that are performed by recommend-holding saints as young as 12. Acts in the temple are done either for oneself or on behalf of someone else. Mormons call this “proxy.” We believe that the dead are spiritually alive and capable of accepting the gospel.

We also believe that certain ordinances are essential for doing so. By serving for and in behalf of them by proxy, we grant them the opportunity to receive all promises available to the living. A faithful saint will hopefully perform each ordinance for themselves one time, and thereafter only do it in the service of the dead.

The ordinances are as follows:

  • Baptism and confirmation by proxy
  • Ordination into priesthood (for deceased males)
  • Endowment
    • Initiatory
    • Receiving the endowment (commonly called a “session”)
  • Sealing

I’ll explain each below as well as try to give the reader a picture of what it’s like without demeaning the sacred nature of it.

Proxy Baptism
Baptisms and confirmations for the dead are the only ordinances done by children, and others who have not been “endowed” (more on that later), with the exception of sealings for families converting to the gospel.

Temple baptisms are pretty straightforward. Participants are walked into a font that may look similar to the one above (the oxen represent Ephraim ushering the twelve tribes of Israel). A priesthood holder will then say a prayer including the name of the person for whom the baptism is performed and submerge the participant into the water completely. This is repeated many times, each person usually doing at least a handful of names before finishing.

Priesthood Confirmation

Confirmations simply involve a person sitting in a chair as priesthood holders lay their hands on their head and say a prayer for the deceased person receiving the priesthood. Pretty much just like the image below, but the chairs are more comfy, the surrounding is beautiful and those offering the prayer may have a chair or stool to sit on as well.

Temple Endowment

The endowment consists of two parts, the initiatory and the presentation (session). Initiatories are quick and consist of one being symbolically cleansed and anointed, after which they receive blessings related to their divine heritage. Most members doing initiatories for others will do anywhere from 5–15 at a time, depending on how much time is available.

The session portion of the endowment consists of a presentation of material, including “instruction on how all people can return to the presence of the Lord.”

[1]

Today, most temples use video for certain segments of the presentation. Only a few temples still use actors for the entire thing (“live session”). There are currently multiple videos of the presentation in rotation, all of them are produced in English and later translated into many languages.

(Sidenote: According to rumors I’ve heard, there is a possibility that the church is doing/planning on making films based around certain areas which would contain a more local-looking cast, local language, and stylistic form resembling local style. Just rumors, but pretty interesting stuff to me.)

Other pieces of the ceremony are conducted by temple workers, male and female. The endowment session ends with the participant in the “Celestial Room,” a lounge area beautified to represent heaven. Many people will spend some time there quietly before leaving. Most sessions will take about 2–3 hours total, depending on crowds, etc. and they are performed for only one person at a time.

Temple Sealings

Sealing is the “crowning blessing of the temple.”

[2]
To be “sealed” means that your family is bound together forever. This unity is the goal for our entire human race.

The sealing power is referred to in Matt 16:19: “And I will give thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.”

The ordinance itself is very brief and rather informal compared to other temple work. These occur in “sealing rooms” which have a bunch of chairs, an altar and usually mirrors on opposite walls (the mirrors are not part of the ceremony, but are often used to represent eternity as the mirrors reflect off each other infinitely). The officiator generally offers counsel and some spiritual thoughts, followed by a prayer of blessings promised to the couple (or family) who kneel at the altar while holding hands. The whole thing, including wait time, is usually about an hour or so.

Sealings are bonds that transcend mortal existence. As such, they are held with deep reverence. It’s also important to note that the sealing of families is not dependent on blood kinship. Many LDS families will adopt and seal children, thus creating an eternal family where all are united as one. As I said before, the unity of the human family is paramount to our belief system. We view the work done in the temple with solemnity and see it as a fulfillment of the final promise (as well as the final words) of the Old Testament.

“Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord: And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers, lest I come and smite the earth with a curse.” - Malachi 4:5–6

To learn more about the sealing power, check out my answer to another question What do Muslims and Christians think of Jews?

Original question: Do Mormons keep their temples secret?

No. At temple would be pretty hard to hide, don’t you think? We post their exterior and interior photos online. We post articles and videos about the reason we build temples. What makes them different, and what we do inside. The temples’ addresses and phone numbers are on the web page, too. Here is the link.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

Before each temple is dedicated, there is an open house. All are invited. Visitors learn the purpose of each room and ask any questions they like. We hope they feel some of the holiness of this sacred place.

If you’re ever in the Washington DC area, please come by our temple’s visitors’ center. Maybe I’ll see you there.

Here’s a secret for you. We are no longer called “Mormons” except by the bigoted or ignorant. We are Latter-day Saints.

How does the temple endowment benefit Mormons?

In the Book of Mormon studied by members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, both Lehi and his son Nephi have a vision of the tree of life. The vision is recorded in 1 Nephi chapter 8, and Nephi records the interpretation starting in chapter 11. I highly recommend you read these excellent chapters!

The tree of life and its amazing fruit are likened to the love of God. The rod of iron that people hold and follow to the tree is the word of God. By holding fast to the word of God, we are led to the tree and the love of God.

The temple endowment is a blessing of knowledge and covenants that we make as individuals. It builds on and enhances the covenants we make when we are baptized. These covenants of keeping the commandments, sacrificing to build up the kingdom of God on the earth, and serving to help and lift others can help keep us holding fast to the iron rod, or the word of God, and help move us forward on the path to reaching the full love of God.

Can I just walk into a Mormon temple?

Original question: Can I just walk into a Mormon temple?

This is a great question. Short answer, yes. Also, no. But hold on, you deserve better.

In my experience, a lot of people say “Mormon temple” when they mean a meetinghouse of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. These places are numerous, located in residential areas in just about every city and town in North America, and usually have a plaque on the front of the building that says the name of the Church and VISITORS WELCOME. Original question: Can I just walk into a Mormon temple?

This is a great question. Short answer, yes. Also, no. But hold on, you deserve better.

In my experience, a lot of people say “Mormon temple” when they mean a meetinghouse of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. These places are numerous, located in residential areas in just about every city and town in North America, and usually have a plaque on the front of the building that says the name of the Church and VISITORS WELCOME. You can just walk in, and like the sign says, you will be welcome. I hope you come this Sunday. Here’s how to find them.

Meetinghouse Locator | LDS Maps
{{selected.active.properties.HoursCode | day}} {{selected.active.properties.Hours}} First meeting {{selected.active.properties.HoursCode | day}} {{selected.active.properties.WorshipService}} Sacrament meeting {{selected.active.properties.HoursCode | day}} {{selected.active.properties.WorshipService}} Sacrament meets first
https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/maps/meetinghouses/@38.995353,-77.222666,12

But that’s not the end. When you hear a Latter-day Saint refer to “the temple,” it’s not the same as the meetinghouse. They are less numerous, and only exist where there is a large, permanent population of Latter-day Saints. They are not centers of weekly public worship, but rather sacred rites. In fact, they are closed on Sundays. They are open only to people with written recommendations. You can identify a temple because it has a sign that includes the word “TEMPLE” and over the door you will see THE HOUSE OF THE LORD. Without a recommend, you can only go as far as the front desk in the lobby. Here is how to find the temple.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/temples/list?lang=eng

Without a recommend, this is as far as you’ll get in the temple.

When you are spiritually prepared, which is not a small thing, you will be invited into the temple. Some people change the whole direction of their lives just to be able to go to the temple and make covenants with God that can only be received there.

Some temples have an adjacent visitors’ center, open to the public. You’re invited. Many temples also have a meetinghouse next door. You’re invited there, too.

BUT WAIT, THERE’S MORE!

After the temple is built or renovated, there is an open house. We invite as many people as we can. Typically, the first day is for the media, the second day is for politicians and leaders of other religious denominations, and then two or three weeks for the general public. This is the only time you can just walk in and get a tour. I’m glad you asked this question now because the Church is building more temples now than ever before. Over the next three years there are going to be tons of open houses, culminating in the granddaddy of them all, the open house of the Salt Lake Temple in approximately 2024. Check this link for the announcments, and you might find one near you. I hope you can make it.

https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/temples/open-houses?lang=eng
Open House – August 5, 2023 - August 26, 2023 Open house tours and activities hosted daily (except for Sundays). More detailed information about the open house will be posted when available. Temple Dedication – Sunday, September 17, 2023
https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/temples/open-houses?lang=eng

Earlier this month, the open house was held for the Mesa Arizona Temple, after a renovation. This video reports on the first day of the event.

I hope this is helpful.

How do Mormon temples differ from regular churches?

Churches are for Sunday services and weekly events. Temples are closed Sundays.

Temples are used only for services that recommend holders can attend. They are either marriages, baptisms for the dead, or endowments.

What is a sealing room in a Mormon temple?

It’s a room where husbands and wives and whole families are sealed for eternity. Eternal marriages take place in sealing rooms. If a couple is converted to the Church after being married in a civil ceremony or in another church, they will be sealed in the temple after a year. If they have children born before they are married in the temple, those children will also be sealed to them. Children born to a couple after they are married in the temple are automatically sealed to them since they are born under the marriage covenant.

When did Mormons start performing sealings in temples?

This is a most interesting question. First there are no Mormons. There are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the only name of which the organization, practices and beliefs can be indentified. Please change your nominclature.

This is a most interesting question. First there are no Mormons. There are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the only name of which the organization, practices and beliefs can be indentified. Please change your nominclature.

Sealings started in the Nauvoo Temple, but only for the living relationships of members. And there were members who did not understand that sealings were for families then existing, not some other relationship one might want in the eternities. Thus, some people sought to be sealed to leaders of the church or some other fantasy situation one would have in the next life. Also if one was coming to be sealed later on in life, one did not think about ones children who they obviously hoped to have a relationship beyond the veil. So sealings of children to parents was not an intial practice in the church.

Most of this was cliarified with President Wilford Woodruff, when the first temple was opened in St. George, Utah after the exodus and replanting the church was completed under Brightam young. But the practice of sealing did not stop for the years intervening. Without a fully operational temple Brigham Young built what was called the Endowment House in Salt Lake City. Thus, worthy members could continue a limited temple process including sealings during this interim period.

Doing temple work for the dead, did not start until Wilford Woodruff was commanded by God to offer these opertunities for the Founding Fathers of The Untied States, who appeared to him in the St. George Temple and requested that such work be done. Much of the church’ s understanding of temple work came from President Woodruff’s revelations on the subject.

Just to put context on the subject, the Salt Lake Temple took over 40 years to build. It was started by Brigham Young, stopped when johnson’s army put down the “rebellion” out in the Utah Territory, started again when they found the foundation had to be pulled out and redone as the wrong material had been chosen, then continued building. Wilford Woodruff dedicated it when completed in 1893.

It has been closed for the past nearly three years to reneovation. You are invited to attend the open house in 2024 or 2025 as the open house is expected to run six months. Check the progress of the possibilities so when it is announced you can tour it and see the sealing rooms as well as all the other pioneer artistry that went into this legendary edifice.

Can Mormons (LDS) be members of other religions at the same time and still be allowed in the temple?

Technically, yes…but not really.

For example, while people often complain that it is supposedly “impossible” to leave The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (even though you just need to submit a written request to be removed from records), it really is just about impossible to leave Catholicism. If you’ve been baptized Catholic, they will more or less consider you Catholic forever. So there are many members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints who regularly attend the temple and hold high callings but are, by some account, still considered “Catholic”.

Another example would be how certain countries officially record your religious affiliation and then make it just about impossible to change it, especially if that affiliation is Muslim.

The key item in any such cases is the matter of how the individual self-identifies. We don’t care if another church or a government considers you to be a member of another religion. However, if you consider yourself to be a member of another religion, that is a pretty serious thing. The only possible exceptions might be for religions that border on philosophy and don’t have any direct conflict with our teachings. For example, Confucianism.

Another thing to note is that there are often cultural things that people do that may seem religious in nature but aren’t really. An example is the ancestor worship I saw in Taiwan. Members of the Church who live in Taiwan will frequently “pray” to ancestors, but the reality is that they don’t view that in the same way as their prayers to God. And the reality is that it is just a more formalized version of what many members of the Church already do in other countries anyway.

Temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are fancy because that is what temples are supposed to be.

Our meetinghouses are different, though. They are much more numerous and more mundane for the most part.

Why do Mormons get sealed in the temple?

What sets the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints apart is the sealing power; the power to seal on earth which also seals in heaven. Sealings in the temple seal families together forever, if the individuals remain faithful and accept the sealing. It is in the ordinances that the power of God is manifest. All bonds, obligations, contracts, agreements, etc. made on earth have an end at death except those done through the priesthood.
